La cliente vive en Guayaquil. Comenzó su tienda con pocos víveres, poco a poco fue incrementando su negocio con la ayuda de su esposo (el aparece en la foto). Trabajan todos los días desde muy temprano hasta la noche que cierran el local. En su tienda tiene víveres como arroz, granos, enlatados, confites etc. 

Una de las dificultades de su negocio el transito ya que le dificulta la venta de los víveres. La cliente está casada su esposo es maestro albañil, ellos  tienen 4 hijos, uno de sus hijos tiene un problema de discapacidad. 

Ella tiene muchas aspiraciones con su familia por eso quiere seguir trabajando para mejorar su negocio y darle lo mejor a sus hijos. El préstamo lo usara para mejorar el local donde tiene su tienda, comprando cemento, ladrillos, pintura y así darles una mejor atención a sus clientes. En el futuro quiere terminar el local de su negocio y darle lo mejor a su familia.
texts.en:
This borrower lives in Guayaquil. She started her store with few groceries, but she gradually increased her business with the help of her husband (who also appears in the photo). They work every day, beginning in the early morning hours, and continue until nightfall when they close the shop. Her store is stocked with food items such as rice, grain, canned goods, candy, and other products.

One of the difficulties in her business is dealing with traffic, since it makes it hard to sell groceries. The borrower is married and her husband is a master bricklayer. They have four children, one of whom suffers from a disability.

The borrower has many aspirations for her family, so she wants to continue working in order to improve her business and provide the best for her children. Her loan will be used to improve the space where she has her store. She will buy cement, bricks, and paint since this improvement will help her provide better service to her customers. In the future, she wants to complete the physical improvements to her shop and provide the best for her family.

loans.use: to buy construction materials for making physical improvements to her store.

loans.name: Totala's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe est créé au même moment que le banc villageois. Il regroupe des femmes d’un même quartier, elles partagent aussi des liens de parenté ce qui facilite l’entente et la solidarité entre les membres. En plus du petit commerce, elles font du jardinage collectif.

Madame Totala (debout à l’extrême droite) est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Son activité tourne sur la vente de denrées de consommation dans le village en plus de l’activité de maraichage et cela depuis des années. 

Son prêt lui permettra d’augmenter son stock en vu d’accroître sa capacité de financement et son revenu.

Avec les retombées, elle compte améliorer la nourriture familiale.
texts.en:
This group was created at the same time as the Banc Villageois.  It gathers women who come from the same neighborhood and also share family ties, which makes it easier for them to get along with one another and facilitates solidarity among the members.  In addition to retail, these women are involved in collective gardening.

Totala (standing at the far right in the photo) is the group's featured borrower.  Her business revolves around market gardening and selling food products in the village.  She has been involved in this activity for many years.

Thanks to her loan, she will be able to increase her stock, which will consequently boost her financing capacity and income.

With the profits, she is planning to improve her family's diet.

loans.use: to increase her stock of food products in order to boost her financing capacity and her income.

loans.name: Deonila

texts.en:
This is Deonila. Her previous loan was a big help, not just in her business. She was able to buy more products for her variety store. The loan also helped with her family's everyday expenses. She has been in this business for nine years now. She and her husband are working hard to continuously provide for their everyday needs and expenses.

She would like to apply for a new 35,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Deonila dreams to have another store and hopes that her family will live happily. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Posia

texts.en:
Posia is 46 years old and married with four children. She owns and operates a small store, selling items such as frozen products, food supplies and many more things. She has been doing this for three years. 

Posia needs a loan to buy new goods and products for her shop. She hopes to use her profits to support her family and kids. She became a member of SPBD in 2011 to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: to buy chicken legs, mutton flab, Coca-Cola, Sprite, cooking oil, sugar, salt and flour.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
This is Amelia. She previously accessed an 18,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan that she used to purchase quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for a new 22,000 PHP loan to buy additional supplies of raw materials like different kinds of fabric, thread and other items needed in her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Amelia dreams that her business will continue to grow and hopes to have a happy family. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw materials like different kinds of fabric, thread and other items needed in her business.

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
This is Josie. She previously received a 16,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread, and other materials needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household, and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 24,000 PHP loan for her to buy additional supplies of raw materials like foam, fabric, threads, and other materials needed in her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her family’s daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Josie dreams for a continuous growth in her business. She meets up every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials like foam, fabric, threads and other materials she needs in her business.

loans.name: Benilda

texts.en:
This is Benilda. She previously received a 50,000 PHP loan that she used to buy ingredients and bottles for her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household, and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan for her to buy calamansi (Panama orange) scent, other ingredients, and bottles needed for her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her family’s daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Benilda hopes to expand her business. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for calamansi (Panama orange) scent, other ingredients, and bottles needed for her business.

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita is married, and she works hard to support her family.

She has a guitar-making business in the Philippines. Pacita is borrowing 13,000 PHP through NWTF to buy materials needed for her guitar-making business.

Pacita has been sustaining her business activities through her past six loans from NWTF and, more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy materials needed for her guitar-making business.

loans.name: Idalina

texts.en:
A loan of $1,000 is offered to Idalina to improve her business. She opened her kiosk in 2009 with $100 of her own working capital. She will use the loan to buy stocks to keep in her store like noodles, oil, sugar, coffee, soap, milk, rice and slippers. Idalina is generating a good income from selling.
She has been thinking of running a big business after years of involving herself in doing business. Idalina is living in a town with her family.

loans.use: To buy noodles, oil, sugar, coffee, soap, milk and rice

loans.name: Rubelyn

texts.en: Rubelyn, 25 years old, is single and a bread winner of the family. She supports her parents in the daily expenses for her brother and sister. Rubelyn works in a private company. She is requesting a loan of PHP 25,000 to buy cement, iron and other materials to be used for the renovation of their house because she wants to have a better shelter for her parents. Rubelyn hopes that she can meet all the needs of her parents so that she can save money for her future family.

loans.use: to buy cement, iron and other materials to be used in home repairs and renovations.

loans.name: Maria Linda

texts.en:
Maria Linda is married and works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 26,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell at her store.

Maria Linda has been in this business for four years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Maria Linda successfully repaid her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Maria Linda aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell at her store.

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en: Natividad, 54, is requesting a loan in order to develop her piggery business. An amount of 15,000 PHP will purchase two piglets to raise, vitamins to improve their health, and feed. This will help her to be more profitable and successful. She believes that with hard work she will been able to improve her family's financial status as well as the educational prospects of her three children.

loans.use: to purchase two piglets to raise, vitamins to improve their health, and feed

loans.name: Janett

texts.en:
This is Janett. She previously received a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments, and seasonings. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household, and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan to purchase raw ingredients and supplies needed in her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Janett hopes that her business will continue to grow and have a bigger income to help others. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week so that she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients like rice, pork, chicken, vegetables, and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Nasrin

texts.en:
Nasrin is from northern Israel. She is well-known in her area as a creative and talented artist. Through the help and encouragement of her family, Nasrin opened a store selling toys, children's clothing, gift items, purses, bags scarves and costume jewelry. She also sells items she has created and has gained a good reputation. The diversity of items are well in demand in her area, and her store is centrally located with both new and returning customers. Nasrin has also expanded, including a corner for manicures and artificial nails, a wonderful addition to her business.

Nasrin needed this loan for shelving, a jewelry stand, stock of jewelry, bags, scarves, toys, a manicure station and materials.

Nasrin is dedicated to her growing business and believes in its potential. She wants to continue and see her business strengthen as her family grows.

loans.use: To buy shelving, a jewelry stand, stock of jewelry, bags, scarves, toys, a manicure station and materials.

loans.name: Nicida

texts.es:
Nicida de 27 años de edad , esta casada y tiene 3 hijos con quienes reside en su vivienda en calidad de alquiler .Desde hace 7 años brinda atención en su tienda de productos comestibles el cual se encuentra ubicado en el primer piso de la vivienda de su suegra ,al tener ubicado su negocio en una esquina de su barrio le ha permitido tener buena clientela haciendo a su vez muchas amistades.
En su negocio podemos hallar diversos productos considerados de primera necesidad tales como arroz, azúcar, gaseosas, enlatados y diversos consumibles con mayor demanda entre su distinguida clientela.
Uno de los principales inconvenientes que aquejan las ganancias finales de su negocio es el retraso en el pago de productos que brinda al crédito.Sus objetivos económicos a largo plazo son el de adquirir un terreno para la construcción de su vivienda ya que considera una buena manera de invertir a futuro.Este viene a ser su primer crédito otorgado por Kiva , por esta razón esta agradecida por la oportunidad brindada y se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual.
Desea contar con 3,000 nuevos soles para surtir su negocio con mas productos tales como cereales, gaseosas, conservas y golosinas esperando mantener o mejorar la afluencia de su clientes.
texts.en:
Nicida is 27 years old, is married and has three children with whom she lives in her rented home. She has been working in her store of food products for seven years. It is located in the first floor of the house of her mother in law. Since her business is located in a corner of her neighborhood, this has allowed her to have many customers as well as to make many friendships.

In her business we can find many products considered necessities such as rice, sugar, soft drinks, canned food and other consumables with high demand among her distinguished customers. One of the main problems affecting the profits is the delay in paying the products she sells on credit. Her long term financial goal is to buy a land where to build a house, because she thinks it's a good way to invest in her future. 

This is her first loan from Kiva, for this reason she is very grateful for the opportunity given and is committed to pay her installments on time. She needs 3,000 nuevos soles to supply her business with more products such as cereals, soft drinks, canned food and sweets, hoping to maintain and improve the flow of customers.

loans.use: to buy products such as rice, cereals, soft drinks, and others.

loans.name: Evita

texts.en:
Evita is a 52-year-old man from Rwamagana District in the Eastern Province of Rwanda. He is seeking a loan of $50 to purchase 10 rechargeable LED lights, which he will resell to people without electricity in his village. Every week or so, these customers will return to him to have their lights recharged for just $0.20. 

Evita started selling lights in February, 2012, and he has sold 40 lights to date, providing clean energy to 200 people. He is also a shopkeeper and will reinvest the money he makes into expanding his other business to earn more money for himself and his wife.

loans.use: To pay for 10 low-cost LED lights to resell to rural households without electricity.

loans.name: Awen Indah Group

texts.en:
With nine members, the Awen Indah continue their loan of 13,500,000 IDR and each receive 1,500,000 IDR. They decided to continue the loan until they have enough savings.

Ni Komang will use her loan to purchase three superior piglets for fattening. According to her plan, the pigs will be ready to sell in the month of May. The profit will be used to buy a sow. She has a plan to become a piglet seller, especially of local pigs.

She hopes her plan will come true, and she can improve her business by selling piglets to other breeders.

loans.use: to purchase three superior piglets for fattening

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is a 42-year-old man from Rwamagana District in the Eastern Province of Rwanda. He is seeking a loan of 30,000 RWF to purchase 10 rechargeable LED lights, which he will resell to people without electricity in his village. Every week or so, these customers will return to him to have their lights recharged for just $0.20. Emmanuel started selling lights in May 2012 as the chairman of his business group, and he has sold 120 lights to date, providing clean energy to 600 people. He is also a shopkeeper and will reinvest the money he makes into expanding his other business to earn more money for himself, his wife, and his children.

loans.use: to pay for 10 low-cost LED lights to resell to rural households without electricity.

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en: Chantha is 22 years old. He is a farmer’s son who lives in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia. Currently, he is employed in a financial institution as a credit officer. He makes an income of $4 daily. To be employed in a governmental institution is Chantha’s dream. Therefore, he has enrolled in Royal University of Law and Economics and plans to graduate in 2015. Chantha is requesting a loan of $1000 to pay for his tuition fees. This money will help him complete his degree and fulfill his dream. He expects to earn more money when he graduates with his bachelor’s degree.

loans.use: to pay for his tuition fees

loans.name: Catalina

texts.es: Doña Catalina de 59 años de edad viven en casa propia con su familia, es una mujer muy responsable y trabajadora, ha logrado sacar adelante a su familia. Ella posee una tienda de productos comestibles como pan, refrescos, aceites, verduras, frutas, golosinas y también de primera necesidad como: jabón y shampoo entre otras cosas tiene su negocio en su casa de habitación. Doña Catalina solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda surtir aún más la tienda de manera que pueda atender mejor a sus clientes y de esta misma forma mejorar sus ventas lo cual es su prioridad para sacar adelante su hogar.
texts.en:
Catalina, 59 years old, lives in her own home with her family. She is a very responsible and hard-working woman, and has managed to provide for her family. She owns a shop that sells food items like bread, soft drinks, oils, vegetables, fruits and candies. She also sells consumer staples like soap and shampoo, among other things.

Catalina is asking for a loan to be able to carry even more stock at the store and better serve the needs of her customers. In this way, she will improve her sales, which is her priority in order to support her household.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith is 18 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Faith has been working hard to manage her soap business, which makes soap for sale. 

To help expand her business, Faith has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy products to make soap, and will help Faith to generate greater profits and afford to maintain the business. Faith hopes that in the future, she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Faith is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy products to make soap.

loans.name: Jovia's Group

texts.en:
Jovia's group comprises four hardworking women. Jovia is 18 years old and lives in the town of Hima in the Fortportal region of Uganda. She is single and has one child. For the past three years, Jovia has been working hard to manage her clothes store where she sells secondhand clothes. 

To help expand her business, Jovia has requested a loan of 700,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes to sell. This will help Jovia to generate greater profits and improve her standard of living. Jovia hopes that in the future she will be able to boost her business. 

Rose is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en:
Immaculate is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. For the past four months, Immaculate has been working hard to manage her charcoal business, which sells charcoal and cassava flour. 

To help expand her business, Immaculate has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to start another charcoal business in town, which will help Immaculate to generate greater returns and lead to increased profit. Immaculate hopes that in the future she will be able to live a good life. 

Immaculate is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to start another charcoal business in town

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is 41 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. He is married and has two children, with one of them currently in school. For the past five years, Jackson has been working hard to manage his small clothing business, in which he sells clothes. 

To help expand his business, Jackson has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more cartons of clothes to sell, and will help Jackson to generate greater profits and improve his family's stadands of living. Jackson hopes that in the future, he will be able to expand his business into a wholesale shop. 

Jackson is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small-scale entrepreneurs like Jackson who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to stock more cartons of clothes to sell.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James used the previous loan to buy produce to sell. He is a 46-year-old gentleman, living in Kagadi, Uganda. He sells local brew and has been in business for a period of four years. Inadequate capital is the factor affecting the business, however, he would like to educate his two children and set up a big food store that can supply at least three districts. 

James is requesting a loan to buy maize and beans to sell.

loans.use: to buy maize and beans to sell.

loans.name: Kesa

texts.en:
Kesa is 37 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga, in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has five children, who are all currently in school. For the past 15 years, Kesa has been working hard to manage his retail shop, where he sells items like soap, sugar, milk and bread. 

To help expand his business, Kesa has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. He will use the loan to purchase more items to resell at his store, such as rice, maize flour and soda. This will help Kesa to generate greater profits and to pay school fees for his children. He hopes that, in the future, he will be able to produce quality products for the shop. 

Kesa is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program serves primarily small entrepreneurs like Kesa, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more items to resell at his store, such as rice, maize flour and soda

loans.name: John Bosco

texts.en: John Bosco used the previous loan to buy spare parts to sell. He is a 32-year-old, hardworking man with one child living in Fort Portal, Uganda. After realizing the need for more capital to live a modest life, he started a motorcycle spare-parts shop. His personal goals are buying a plot and building a good residential house. His business plan is diversifying the business to include motor vehicle spare parts. John Bosco is requesting for a loan to buy motorcycle spare parts to sell.

loans.use: to buy motorcycle spare parts to sell.

loans.name: Nulu

texts.en:
Nulu is widowed with five children, and only two of her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (father and mother). 

Nulu has a business of knitting sweaters and table mats. She has been in this business for ten years. She has applied for a loan of 2,000,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more thread, needles and another knitting machine. She works in the shop six days out of every week and sells on a retail basis.  

Nulu generates additional income from rental rooms. Her major business challenges include transportation and defaulters. She aspires to own a knitting school and also to become a supplier of sweaters at wholesale. 

She resides in her own house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses includes school fees and paying for utility bills.

loans.use: to buy more thread, needles and another knitting machine.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a single mother of three children and one of her children goes to school. She also takes care of her father. Margaret has a business selling green bananas. She has been in this business for two years selling to all categories of people but on a retail basis only.  She generates additional income by working as a vounteer .  She works at the market seven days out of every week.  

Margaret has applied for a loan from MCDT SACCO to buy more bunches of green bananas. Her major business challenges include transportation of bunches of green bananas and seasonality. She aspires to become a wholesaler and also to build rental rooms. She resides in her own house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water.  Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of green bananas.

loans.name: Lukia

texts.en:
Lukia is a 45-year-old widow with four children, all of them at school.

She has a retail shop, and a banana plantation where she gets some additional income. 

Her business started in 2000 with challenges, but as of now it has stabilized and she can get income to support her family and also pay tuition for her children at university. Her clients are people from within and around the area she resides because she serves as a monopolist. 

She took a loan of UGX 1,300,000. She hopes to expand her business so as to meet the ever growing market for the products. She is a committed, self-reliant woman who freely associates with the local people. She thanks the bank for financial support at reduced interest.

loans.use: To buy stock items for the retail shop.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel lives in Maphombe, a small town in Kwale county. Kwale county is located on the Kenyan coast and is the southernmost Kenyan county. Though some of the towns along the beach see benefits from tourism, the majority of people living inland are farmers, and the region's inconsistent rains can make agricultural yields unpredictable. Beekeeping is a relatively new activity in the area, but many farmers here are enthusiastic at the prospect of owning their own hives and gathering additional income from the sale of their honey.

Daniel is married and has four children. Both he and his wife have been farming for thirty-six years, and they are currently tending to an orange orchard on their land. Daniel is excited to work with Honey Care Africa because their hive technicians provide very good service and teach people about beekeeping. He also wants to become a beekeeper because he loves eating honey.

This is Daniel’s first loan, and he plans to use the money generated by his beehives to help build a house.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en:
Oliver is 45 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. she is married and has 5 children who are all currently in school. For the past 4 years, Oliver has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells soap, sugar, milk and bread.

To help expand his business, Oliver has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more items such as rice, maize flour and soda to sell, and will help Oliver to generate greater profits and pay some of the school fees for her children. Oliver hopes that in the future she will be able to pay school fees for her children.
Oliver is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Oliver who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more items such as rice,maize flour and soda to sell,

loans.name: Ludovico

texts.pt:
Solteiro sem filhos ainda, vive na casa cedida pelo Estado e não sustenta mais ninguém.
É docente numa escola local e com o presente empréstimo pretende legalizar o seu terreno para construir sua residência. 
No futuro deseja construir quartos de aluguer para aumentar o seu rendimento mensal, para tal compromete-se a pagar devidamente o empréstimo para solicitar mais a Hluvuku. 
O desafio é trabalhar e procurar uma outra fonte de receita para ultrapassar as dificuldades financeiras que limitam os seus planos.
texts.en:
Ludovico is single and doesn't have any children yet. He lives in a house lent to him by the State and doesn't support anyone else.

He's a teacher in a local school and with this loan he plans to legalize his piece of land in order to be able to build his house on it.

In future Ludovico hopes to build extra rooms to rent out so as to increase his monthly income. To this end he commits to duly paying off the loan so that he can solicit further loans from Hluvuku.

His challenge is to keep working and to look for another source of income to overcome the financial difficulties which currently limit his plans.

loans.use: legalize his piece of land in order to be able to build his house on it

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed is a 29-year-old single man who completed secondary school. He lives in a small house with his family (his mother, brothers, and sisters) in Sana'a, Yemen. His father is working in Saudi Arabia, and helped him to open a cosmetics and accessories store. 

Mohammed started this business in 2011 with the help of his father and mother. The store is making good profit. He wants to expand and buy new merchandise to meet the demands of various groups of customers, so he applied for a YER 500,000 loan from AMB. This loan will enable him to make additional profit. 

Mohammed looks forward to getting married very soon, and enrolling his sisters in private schools to receive a better education and make their own future.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics and accessories to sell.

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed is 24 years old and lives in Taiz, Yemen. He is a single man. 

For the past seven years, Mohammed has been working hard to manage his grocery store, which his mother helped him start. 

To help expand his business, he has applied for a loan of 200,000 YER from AMB. The loan will be used to purchase more grocery items to sell due to his increased stock, and will help him generate greater profits.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items for his business.

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mohammed, 29 years-old, is a Yemeni youth client. He lives with his parents in Taiz, Yemen ,and he is the breadwinner of his family. He has not gotten married yet because he doesn`t have enough money to improve his living standards. Now, he owns a retail store which is very old and needs a renovation, so he requested a youth loan in the amount of 150,000 YER from AMB to buy construction supplies. Mohammed looks forward to growing his business more, so that he would be able to expand it and open a grocery store.

loans.use: to buy construction supplies to renovate his store

loans.name: Aramata's Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe baribalna qui signifie courage est créé lors de la mise en place du banc villageois. Les membres vivent dans un même quartier et partagent des liens de solidarité depuis plusieurs années. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Aramata (debout à l’extrême droite) est l’emprunteuse vedette. Elle est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Elle achète des produits tirés de l’agriculture ou du maraichage dans les marchés hebdomadaires pour la revente dans son village. Cette activité elle l’a pratique depuis plus de sept ans.

Ce nouveau crédit lui permettra de relancer son activité par l’acquisition de nouveaux stocks de produits  agricole et alimentaire.

Avec les bénéfices, elle compte contribuer de manière significative à la gestion de la famille.
texts.en:
The Baribalna group - which means courage - was created during the implementation of the local "banc villageois". Members live in the same neighborhood and have developed a group spirit for several years. Their main activity is to run small businesses.

Mrs. Aramata (standing at the far right) is the featured borrower. She is married and has three children. She buys agricultural products or fresh produce from the weekly markets for resale in her village. She has been conducting this activity for more than seven years.

This new loan will enable her to boost her business by acquiring new stocks of food and agricultural products.

With the profits she intends to contribute significantly to her family's needs.

loans.use: boost her business by acquiring new stocks of food and agricultural products.

loans.name: Nguvu Group

texts.en:
Nguvu Group is located in Kakamega North District. It is a group of seven women and three men, led by Rosemary, who is pictured on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of millet and sorghum cultivation. Rosemary is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and use her increased profits to send her children to school.

Rosemary managed to harvest 2 1/2 bags of maize on 1 1/2 acres of land last year. As a One Acre Fund farmer, she hopes to harvest much more! She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and to save for the future. Nguvu Group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total, they will receive inputs for 5 acres of millet and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Madeleine's Group

texts.fr:
le banc villageois a été créé le 14/06/2002. le groupe comprend 07 femmes qui habitent le même quartier,il est a son 22eme prêt ,leur activité principal est le commerce.

Madeleine est le représentante du groupe,elle a levé sa main sur la photo, elle est veuve et mère de 4 enfants dont 2 garçons. Elle fait de l'aviculture chez elle ,elle n'est pas la seule a faire cet activité dans le quartier, mais elle arrive a s'en sortir.En plus de cela elle à une activité parallèle dont elle s'y connait beaucoup, qui est l'embouche de porc.

Avec ses bénéfices elle paie la scolarité de ses enfants et gère ses épargne dans le banc villageois .
texts.en:
This group is made up of seven women who live in the same neighborhood. It belongs to a "banc villageois" that was established on June 14, 2002. The members of the group are seeking their 22nd loan, and their main business is trade.

Madeleine, the group's representative, is the one raising her hand in the photograph. She's a widow and the mother of four children. Two of them are boys.

She raises poultry at her home. She's not the only one in this field in her neighborhood, but she manages to get by. In parallel, she also fattens pigs, a business that she knows very well.

With her profits, she pays her children's education and puts away money in the "banc villageois".

loans.use: to buy 50 chicks, food, and 3 pigs

loans.name: Kaujakito Group

texts.en:
Livingstone’s group has 20 farmers and is located in the Teso District. Livingstone is pictured on the right of the Kaujakito Group with his hand raised. Livingstone is pictured amongst the 7 men and 13 women of his group. He will receive input loans capable of planting ½ an acre with sorghum, millet, and sweet potatoes. Livingstone is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. He joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to the best input prices of hybrid seed and fertilizer.

Livingstone described his harvest last year as good, but hopes he can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer. He plans on using future profits from the harvest to send his children to school and buy cattle. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Livingstone’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 10 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Bulangalire Group

texts.fr: La cliente Lubalira est présidente adjoint du groupe d’affaire Bulangalire, jeune entrepreneur expérimentée, âgée de 29 ans et mère de 9 enfants qui  étudient tous. Son conjoint fait le petit commerce de divers.  La cliente est vendeuse des denrées alimentaires. Elle étale ses produits au long de la route principale dite la nationale 4.  Elle commença cette affaire avec son fonds propre reçu de son mari. Plus tard, elle bénéficia le crédit additionnel de Hekima. Il y a 7 ans, que elle exerce cette activité. Ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d’acheter 1 sac de farine de manioc, 1 sac de farine de maïs, 1 bidon d’huile de palme, 50 kg de fretins, 50 kg d’oignons, 2 casiers de Fanta, etc. Elle souhaite augmenter son capital et scolariser ses enfants. Au finish, elle remercie fortement Hekima pour son soutien en microcrédit aux petits entrepreneurs. Il sied de signaler que vers l’horizon, il y a des enfants non invités, qui ont apparu sur la photo du groupe
texts.en: Lubalira is vice-president of the Bulangaire Group.  She is a young, experienced entrepreneur, 29-years old, and mother of 9 children who all attend school.  Her spouse has a small goods store.  Lubalira is a seller of food.  She spreads her merchandise along the main road called National 4.  She started her business with her own funds received from her husband.  Later, she received an additional loan from Hekima.  She has been in business for seven years.  This new loan will enable her to buy 1 bag of manioc flour, 1 bag of corn flour, 1 jug of palm oil, 50 kg of minnows, 50 kg of onions, 2 crates of Fanta, etc. She wishes to increase her working capital and to send her children to school.  Lastly, she thanks Hekima for their support of small entrepreneurs via microcredit.  (It should be noted that there are uninvited children who appear in the back of the group photo.)

loans.use: to buy 1 bag of manioc flour, 1 bag of corn flour, 1 jug of palm oil, 50 kg of minnows, 50 kg of onions, 2 crates of Fanta, etc.

loans.name: Akote Group

texts.en:
Patrick is pictured on the right with his hand raised amongst his Akote Group members. The 23 of them, 15 women and 8 men, are farmers in the Teso District. Farming inputs will be delivered to him on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum. Patrick is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. He joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for his family and use the increased profits to send his children to school.

Patrick described his harvest last year as good, but hopes he can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer.
He plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school and save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Patrick’s group will receive 11.5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of sweet potatoes, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Buyanji Group

texts.en:
Partison’s group has 17 farmers and is located in the Chwele District. Partison is pictured on the right of the Buyanji Group with his hand raised. Partison is pictured amongst the 4 men and 13 women of his group. He will receive input loans capable of planting ½ an acre with sorghum and millet. Partison first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2009 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Partison joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and grow enough food for his family.

Partison reports that before One Acre Fund, he was able to grow about 1 bag of maize per ½ acre, but with his One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, he harvested 15 bags per 1/2 acre! He plans on using future profits from the harvest to send his children to school and save for the future. Partison’s group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total they will receive inputs for 8 1/2 acres of millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Mapendo Group

texts.fr: La cliente Rubangiza est vice présidente  du collectif d’affaire Mapendo, entrepreneur dynamique, âgée de 35  ans, mariée et mère de 7 enfants qui étudient. Son conjoint est un chauffeur. La cliente est fournisseur de divers produits au personnel de la MONUSCO (mission de nations unies pour la stabilisation de la République Démocratique du Congo). Elle est dans entrepreneuriat depuis son jeune âge. Elle n’a pas une activité précise, car elle joue plus, sur les opportunités. Toute fois, le gros de ses activités s’opère à partir de téléphone en passant les commandes de produits. Elle est plus installée sur le route de l’aéroport de Kavumu sur la place publique dit rond point Monument. Ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d’acheter  2 cartons de poissons Thompson, 4 box de confitures, nescafés, etc. Les tracasseries policières dans ce site aéroportuaires sont de défis majeurs pour son activité.  Elle souhaite scolariser ses enfants et accroitre l’entreprise. Au finish, elle remercie fortement Hekima pour son soutien aux petits citoyens en microcrédit.Il sied de signaler qu’une cliente porte son bébé.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rubangiza, age 35, is an energetic entrepreneur and the vice president of Mapendo Group. She's married and the mother of seven school-attending children. Her husband is a driver.

She provides various products to MONUSCO personnel (United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo). She's been an entrepreneur since her young age.

She doesn't run a specific business, because she's more trying to catch opportunities. However, the bulk of her business involves ordering products over the phone. She's located on the road to Kavumu airport, on a public space known as Monument roundabout.

This new loan will be used to buy two boxes of  "thompson fish" (jack mackerels), four boxes of jam, instant coffee, etc. Police hassles in the airport area are major challenges for her business.

She would like to send her children to school and expand her business. In conclusion, she greatly thanks Hekima for supporting people of modest means with microloans. It must be noted that one of the women in the group is carrying her baby.

loans.use: to buy two boxes of fish, four boxes of jam, instant coffee, etc

loans.name: Jorge Luis

texts.es:
Jorge es un hombre de 59 años, vive en la ciudad de Ica, el es una persona muy amable, trabajador y entusiasta, que dedica todos sus esfuerzos por salir adelante; lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos y por la necesidad que tuvo de trabajar desde muy joven, Jorge no puso estudiar la carrera profesional de Derecho que deseaba, en sus ratos libre le gusta distraerse viendo televisión y en algunas ocasiones cocina un riquísimo Seco de Pollo para compartir con su familia.
Por iniciativa propia, con mucho empeño y dedicación, Jorge trabaja en el rubro de construcción como albañil y pintor, el trabaja todos los días por un aproximado de 10 horas y cree que le va bien por los buenos detalles, acabados y por el trato amable que brinda a sus clientes.
Jorge se encuentra muy agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la compra de herramientas, como cubos, brochas, martillos, y otros, de esta manera Jorge podrá contar con las herramientas necesarias para seguir brindando sus servicios y poco a poco desea lograr su gran sueño de tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
Jorge, 59, lives in the city of Ica. He is a very friendly, hardworking, and enthusiastic person who dedicates all of his efforts towards achieving success. 

Unfortunately, due to a lack of financial resources and the need to start working at a very young age, Jorge was unable to study a professional degree in Law as he would have liked to. In his free time, he likes to distract himself by watching television, and he sometimes cooks a delicious Seco de Pollo (chicken stew) to share with his family.

By his own initiative and with plenty of effort and dedication, Jorge works in construction as a builder and painter. He works every day for about 10 hours per day, and he believes that his work is going well due to his good details and finishings, as well as the friendly manner in which he treats his clients.

Jorge is very grateful to the Kiva lenders, because thanks to their help he will be able to buy tools such as buckets, brushes, and hammers, among others. Jorge will then have the necessary tools to continue offering his services. Little by little, he hopes to achieve his greatest dream of having his own house.

loans.use: to buy construction supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy materials for sewing.

loans.name: Ubaldina

texts.es:
Ubaldina de 36 años de edad , es soltera , posee una vivienda construida a base de material noble que logro construir con el paso de los años y el apoyo de su ex esposo.Posee un negocio consistente en una tienda de productos comestibles.Inicialmente se dedicaba a las actividades agrícolas concernientes a la producción de cacao orgánico y otros más comerciales de la zona. No obstante desde hace 8 años y con ahorros que acumulo hasta entonces optó por cambiar radicalmente de rubro apostando así por una tienda de abarrotes.A inicios fue algo complicado puesto que al contar con capital reducido adquirió poca mercadería logrando con el paso de los años ampliar su negocio. Suele adquirir sus productos al por mayor puesto que obtiene mejores ganancias y asegura su mercadería por un periodo mas prolongado.Uno de sus principales objetivos aparte de mejorar y ampliar su negocio es adquirir una parcela de cultivo y alquilarlo para incrementar sus ingresos paralelo a su negocio.Este es su primer préstamo con Kiva y se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual.
Con los 1,000 nuevos soles otorgados espera abastecer nuevamente su negocio con sacos de arroz, azúcar, gaseosas, conservas y cereales mas consumidos por su distinguida clientela.
texts.en:
Ubaldina is 36 years old. She is single and has a house made from brick that she was able to build over the years and with the help of her ex-husband. She has a business which consists of a little food store. At first, she worked in agriculture, growing organic cacao and other more commercial products in the area. Nonetheless, 8 years ago, with money she had saved up, she decided to radically change her work and opened a convenience store. At first, it was a little complicated, because she had little capital and didn't acquire very much merchandise. As the years passed, she was able to expand her business. She usually gets products wholesale since that brings in more profits and ensures her merchandise for a longer time. One of her main goals apart from improving and enlarging her business is acquiring a parcel of farmland and renting it out to increase her income with her business. This is her first Kiva loan and she is committed to making her payments on time. 

With the 1,000 nuevos soles she has been lent she hopes to stock her business again with sacks of rice and sugar, sodas, preserves and the most popular grains with her customers.

loans.use: to buy products such as rice, sugar, preserves and more.

texts.es: Kennelis de 28 años de edad vive junto con su compañero de vida y su hijo; ella se dedica al cultivo de frijol y maíz, tiene varios años de trabajar en la agricultura comercia en todos los alrededores de la comunidad, ella es una mujer emprendedora, activa, resposnable y honesta, Kennelis desea realizar una inversión para producir mas cosechas pero necesita de capital por eso le solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar semilla de frijol y maiz, insecticida, herbicida, abono, herramienta, etc. y asi ella podra obtener mejores ganancias que le ayudaran a salir adelante con su familia
texts.en: Kennelis is 28 years old. She lives with her life's companion and her son. She grows beans and corn and has worked in agriculture for several years. She sells all around the community. She is an enterprising, active, responsible and honest woman. Kennelis wants to make an investment to produce more crops but she needs capital. That is why she is asking INTEGRAL for a loan that will allow her to buy bean and corn seeds, insecticides, herbicides, fertilizer, etc. This way she can get more profits that will help her to get ahead with her family.

loans.use: to buy seeds, insecticides, herbicides, fertilizers and tools.

loans.name: Rolando

texts.es: Rolando tiene 33 años de edad , esta casado y tiene una hija de 5 años , actulamente vive en su casa construida a base de madera.Siendo un joven muy trabajador desempeño estudios superiores afueras de su tierra logrando volver con el tiempo aportar a través de su trabajo el impulso para el desarrollo de su localidad.Actualmente viene apoyando como empleado público en la municipalidad de su distrito gracias a su experiencia como buen trabajador.Según comenta lo mejor para crecer como persona es contar con un negocio propio siendo uno de sus objetivos la apertura de una Ferretería para mejorar sus ingresos económicos y por consiguiente su calidad de vida desea seguir trabajando para lograr este objetivo .Este es su primer préstamo con Kiva ,razón por la cual se siente muy agradecido y se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual ya que con los 1,000 nuevos soles comprará una computadora portátil esperando desempeñar su labor de manera fluida y seguir obteniendo buenos ingresos.
texts.en:
Rolando, 33, is married and has a 5-year-old daughter. He lives in a house made from wood. Being a very hardworking young man, he took on a university degree away from home. With time he managed to come back, bringing with him an impulse to develop his town through his work.

He currently supports the municipality of his district as a public employee, thanks to his experience as a good worker. He says that the best way to grow as a person is to have one's own business, so his goal is to open a hardware store to improve his financial income and thus his quality of life. He wishes to continue working to accomplish this goal. 

This is his first loan with Kiva, so he is very grateful and he is committed to paying his dues on time. With these 1,000 Peruvian soles, he will buy a laptop computer, with which he hopes to carry out his work smoothly and to continue earning a good income.

loans.use: to buy a laptop computer.

Gladys described her harvest as good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and to buy cattle. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Gladys’ group will receive 5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.name: Elmer

texts.es:
Elmer de 25 años de edad,esta casado y  asumió la responsabilidad de su familia siendo muy joven , actualmente vive en casa de sus suegros junto a su esposa y su hijo. Su actividad económica se centra en brindar el servicio de planchados en un taller mecánico, desde muy temprano se dirige a su lugar de trabajo ubicado a 1 hora de donde vive. Fue su suegro quien lo incorporo en este rubro, trabajando cerca de 3 años con el. En sus inicios tuvo muchas dificultades, ya que no conocía nada del negocio, pero poco a poco gracias a su empeño y responsabilidad logro aprender y mejorar sus servicios, dejando muy contento a los clientes con su trabajo, por lo que empezó a hacerse conocido y  a realizar trabajos extras por su cuenta. En un futuro esta pensado poner su propio taller.Es así que durante muchos años de experiencia pudo tener un trabajo estable y ahora con las ganancias que le generan sus trabajos extras, pudo comprarse una moto, con el que puede trasladarse de su hogar a su centro de trabajo ahorrándole pasajes. Como un joven entusiasta nos expresa alegre su agradecimiento por el apoyo económico recibido y promete ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas. Siendo este su primer crédito Kiva.
El dinero solicitado de S/.1500 soles lo invertirá en la compra de herramientas que utiliza en su trabajo a diario tales como soldadoras , fierros , entre otros.
texts.en:
Elmer is 25 years old, married and was responsible for his family from quite a young age.  He currently lives with his in-laws alongside his wife and son.  Elmer makes a living as a panel beater in a mechanics' workshop.  He leaves his home very early to arrive at his work, located an hour away.  Elmer's father-in-law helped him get this job after working with him for three years.  In the beginning Elmer had a lot of difficulties as he did not know anything about the business.  However, little by little, thanks to his determination and responsibility, he has learned the job and improved the services he offers.  Now Elmer's customers leave very happy with his work and Elmer is becoming known and is taking on extra work independently.  Elmer is thinking about starting his own workshop in the future.  With many years of experience Elmer was able to find this stable job and now with the money he earns from jobs on the side, he has been able to buy himself a motorbike for getting to and from work, thus saving him money on transport costs.  An enthusiastic young man, Elmer expresses his happiness and thanks for the financial support he has received.  This is his first loan with Kiva and he promises to make his repayments on time.

This loan of 1500 Nuevo Soles will be used to buy tools that Elmer uses on a daily basis.  These include soldering irons, iron and more.

loans.use: to buy tool's for a mechanics' workshop.

loans.name: Yanira Del Carmen

texts.es: Yanira de 45 años de edad, vive junto a su esposo y su hijo, Yanira se dedica a la elaboración de sopa de pata los días jueves y fines de semana, esta sopa es un platillo típico del país que esta elaborada de pata de res, verduras, especias y otros ingredientes más, y debido a su delicioso sabor es muy solicitada y vendida a buen precio, para poder mejorar sus ganancias ella solicita un préstamo y así poder comprar mayor cantidad de materia prima la cual es mucha, y así mismo para mejorar su negocio y percibir mayores ganancias ella desea comprar bebidas para comercializar junto a la sopa, lo que le dará un mejor detalle y aumentara sus ingresos y podra darle a su familia una mejor estabilidad economica.
texts.en: Yanira is 45 years old and lives with her husband and son.  Yanira makes a living making cow's feet soup on Thursdays and weekends.  This soup is one of the country's typical dishes and is made with cow's feet, vegetables, spices and other ingredients.  Given the delicious flavours, it is very popular and sells for a good price.  In order to improve her profits, Yanira is applying for a loan to to buy a much larger quantity of ingredients, to improve her business.  She also wants to make higher profits by buying drinks to sell with the soup.  This will give her more of an edge, increase her income and Yanira will be able to give her family more financial stability.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for making a typical cow's feet soup from El Salvador.

texts.es: Doña Ana vive en casa propia con su esposo y sus tres hijos, es una mujer muy responsable, trabajadora y honrada, trabaja en su propia panadería en la que elabora pan dulce y pan frances sale a venderlo por la colonia donde ella reside y con las ganancia que obtiene y la ayuda de su esposo han logrado cubrir todos los gastos de su hogar, pero doña Ana esta solicitando un credito para realizar una mejora en su casa y esa es construir una fosa para luego hacer los baños ya que con lo que ganan ella y su esposo no les alcanza para cubrir esos gastos y asi van a poder tener su propio baño en su casa.
texts.en: Ana lives in her own house with her husband and three children.  She is responsible, hard-working and honest.  She makes a living with her own bread business.  She makes sweet bread and French bread that she goes out to sell in her local community.  With the profits and with help from her husband, they have managed to cover household costs but Ana is applying for a loan to make some improvements to her house.  She wants to build a pit so that she can then build a bathroom.  With only her and her husband's earnings, Ana cannot afford to cover the costs of the pit but with the loan they will be able to have their own bathroom in their home.

loans.use: to buy materials for improving part of her home.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Hellen was only able to harvest six bags of maize per ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, she was able to harvest 15 bags per ½ acre! She plans on using the future profits from her harvest to send her children to school and buy a cow. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Hellen’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on seven 1/2 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer to cultivate millet and sorghum

loans.name: Theoneste

texts.en:
Theoneste, a 30-year-old man from Ngoma District in the Eastern Province of Rwanda, is seeking a loan of $50 to purchase 10 rechargeable LED lights which he will resell to people without electricity in his village. Every week or so, these customers will return to him to have their lights recharged for just $0.20.

Theoneste started selling lights in September of 2012, and he has sold 20 units to date, providing clean energy to 100 people. He is also a farmer and will reinvest the money he makes into expanding his other business to earn more money for himself and his wife.

loans.use: To pay for 10 low-cost LED lights to resell to rural households without electricity.

loans.name: Rosinah

texts.en:
Rosinah is 32 years old and married to Paul, who contributes to the family income. 

She is a commercial farmer and also owns a fruits and vegetables stall in the market. She has been in the business for a period of about five years with an income of approximately KES 6,000 a month. 

She is taking the first loan from KADET Ltd. and wants to use it to buy farm inputs as well as to add more fruit and vegetables for sale in her stall. She hopes to improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs and more vegetables and fruits for sale.

loans.name: Etadal

texts.en:
Etadal has a hair salon with cosmetic treatments. She is a strong woman who has a special touch with her clients. They appreciate her care and service. Etadal is determined to develop her business and ensure a strong economic future for her family.

Etadal needed this loan for a display closet for creams and hair products, to buy stock of bags and wallets, to paint her salon and add new lighting and treatment products.

Etadal wants to see her business expand to a full salon and treatment center and strengthen her family’s economic future.

loans.use: To purchase a display closet for creams and hair products, to buy stock of bags and wallets, to paint her salon and add new lighting and treatment products.

loans.name: Inuka Group

texts.en:
Inuka Group has 18 farmers and is located in Chwele District. Jenefer is pictured on the right of group with her hand raised. She is among the two men and 16 women of her group. Jenefer is requesting an input loan to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer to cultivate a ½ acre with sorghum and millet. She first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2010 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Jenefer joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for her family and use her increased profits to send her children to school.

Jenefer described her harvest as very good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to buy a cow and send her children to school. Jenefer’s group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total they will receive inputs for nine acres of millet and sorghum.

Rose, one of the farmers of Inuka Group, chose to drop out of the program after this Kiva photo was taken. She is still pictured above.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer to cultivate sorghum and millet

loans.name: Juvenal

texts.en:
Juvenal is a 45-year-old man from Gakenke District in the Northern Province of Rwanda. 

He is seeking a loan of $50 to purchase 10 rechargeable LED lights, which he will resell to people without electricity in his village. Every week or so, these customers will return to him to have their lights recharged for just $0.20. 

Juvenal started selling lights in September, 2012 and he has sold 20 lights to date, providing clean energy to 100 people. He is also a farmer and will reinvest the money he makes into expanding his other business to earn more money for himself and his wife.

loans.use: To pay for 10 low-cost LED lights to resell to rural households without electricity.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
This is Alma. She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, as well as in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for a 15,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and the children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Alma dreams that her business will continue to grow and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed for her business.
